speaker: D
text: So, can you tell us a little bit about yourself, your name, your age, your job, and what you do in your free time?

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, my name is Kush Bhatia. I am 22 years old. I just graduated from Emory University and I work at Visa as a client services associate, and in my free time, I like to explore new restaurants and go to the gym.

speaker: D
text: Great. And can you tell us a little bit about your engagement with Canva as of now?

speaker: Kush
text: As of right now, I don't use Canva primarily as it's not the biggest use within my day to day job at work.

speaker: D
text: Cool. Have you used it in the past before?

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, it was a big thing used throughout my college classes for, like, slide decks to work with people on team presentations and just in my clubs for like marketing reasons.

speaker: D
text: Hmm. So, can you tell me about when you first started using Canva and why you started using it? I mean, you touched on it in your previous answer, but I'd love to hear more about when you were first exposed to the platform. And yeah, if you could just articulate a little bit more about certain use cases that you used the platform for.

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, I think I first really used it when I came to college my freshman year, so I guess four years ago. Okay. When I was trying to join some clubs on campus and I think I applied for one of the marketing positions in one of the business clubs, and I needed to showcase like how I would change what they're currently doing in the club and change it for the future. And I used it mostly for this entrepreneurship club I was in as we were trying to gain clients and gain people to kind of get some funding for our program. So that was the first time I used it.

speaker: D
text: Cool, I see. So in high school, you didn't have much exposure to it at all.

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, I don't think so. No, I don't have any. Yeah.

speaker: D
text: Could I ask what platforms you used instead for like creating digital materials or exploring digital literacy?

speaker: Kush
text: Mm, good question. I think before that, it was mostly just like using, like Google Slides or... yeah, I know that was mostly like Google Slides. Maybe like Microsoft Illustrator… in school.

speaker: D
text: Interesting. Okay. In high school, Microsoft Illustrator?

speaker: Kush
text: Okay, I know what it was called. I can't really remember what the name was. Okay, but like Microsoft, like... what names... whatever they would have in their…

speaker: D
text: Cool. Cool laptops. I see.

speaker: D
text: Okay. So it was basically what your school already had and what was like already integrated into your school's educational platforms.

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, exactly.

speaker: D
text: I see. Okay. Cool. My next question for you is: when did you stop using Canva and what changed, what exactly changed that led you to stop using it?

speaker: Kush
text: I think it was when I graduated in May of this year. Mm hmm. Because I kind of like I was no longer in college clubs, and I wasn't really in an audience area where I needed to create new digital art anymore. And in my current role, I'm not in that kind of role where I need any marketing tools to talk to clients or, like, showcasing digital arts. So that's kind of been a reason why I haven't used it since then.

speaker: D
text: So have you started using any other tools instead of Canva for any type of digital materials?

speaker: Kush
text: I guess in a similar way, but kind of different, and I guess incorporated now it's more so like how to illustrate data, which is through like PowerBI and Tableau. So it's not the same as Canva where you're making a flyer, but to illustrate like media in some way, I guess those are the main ways that I would use it now.

speaker: D
text: Got it, I see. Um, and then I guess when you were using Canva in college, were there any particular challenges or frustrations that made Canva kind of hard to use or less valuable to you?

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, I think early on, when I was using on my own, I wouldn't pay for the service, so there were a lot of barriers to like what you could do and what I wanted to convey through like the digital art. But once I was able to join some clubs, we would pay for the premium package, and then you were able to like get a lot more out of it and do whatever you really wanted to do.

speaker: Kush
text: But also, like, I was very basic on what I would create. I didn't know like how to use a lot of the tools within Canva. I never like really taught myself. So I guess that's another barrier too.

speaker: D
text: I see. Were you ever considering buying Canva Pro for yourself for personal usage at all?

speaker: Kush
text: I did consider it and funny enough, now I remember, within school I did take a Canva class.

speaker: Kush
text: We had a Canva class that I did take, and I had to do it for one semester. So I do remember that now actually.

speaker: D
text: Interesting. Wait, like there was a class?

speaker: Kush
text: Jess—yeah, yeah. So we had like one class that was like you take an Excel class asynchronously for a month or for a semester, and then we had a Canva one, we had an AI one. So I’d take a Canva one one semester.

speaker: D
text: Interesting. Can you explain a little bit more about this class and what it entailed?

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, it was mostly how to sell yourself within a corporate setting and within like using a slide deck within Canva, less digital media of like flyers and stuff like that. But throughout the course, it was… and so we just didn't really have a teacher telling us anything, but we had to create a lot of presentations on certain topics that we were passionate about and also record ourselves on a five-minute presentation and upload it for our, like, teacher I guess who would grade us for it.

speaker: D
text: Hmm, I see. That's super interesting. So the class is for like a corporate context. What is your opinion on Canva within a more professional environment?

speaker: Kush
text: Yeah, so I think it's interesting, because I think it is very useful. Because I know the program that I'm in, we have like—my role is called client services—and next month is called client services month for our entire company. And I know the people that are on the marketing team primarily use Canva and they're the ones talking to a lot of senior leadership and executive VPs. And I know it is a strong tool, especially with how AI is being developed into it, so now it's starting a lot easier for a lot of people because they can just put their prompt and now it's connected to like ChatGPT and Copilot.

speaker: Kush
text: So I think it is a really great tool. It just depends on what your role is within corporate America and if you are able to use it or not use it.

speaker: D
text: Okay, cool. That class is—that's so interesting. I've never heard of like a class that was primarily through Canva, so that's cool. Have you heard in college ever of Canva for Campus or Canva for Education along the same vein?

speaker: Kush
text: I don't think so, no. I haven't heard that.

speaker: D
text: Okay, that's totally fine. And then I guess my final question for you is: would you ever consider coming back to Canva and if so, what would that look like? And if not, why not?

speaker: Kush
text: I mean, I think so. I think one, if it's like a personal reason, I could definitely see myself—if I need a reason to create any digital art, I think it is a good reason. I was actually thinking about doing it on my own to use it for like decorative purposes for like a lot of the art I want to have in my room, and I know I can connect it in that way.

speaker: Kush
text: So on a personal level, yes, I think I would use it. On a professional level, I think if there was ever an opportunity at work where I needed to create something, whether it’s like an employee resource group or if there's an event happening within my— in the Atlanta office or something like that, I would definitely use Canva again.

speaker: Kush
text: So I do see myself using it again, but not right now.

speaker: D
text: I see. Okay, cool. Is there anything else that I didn't specifically ask you about that you want to share? If not, that's totally fine.

speaker: Kush
text: Um no, I think you got it.

speaker: D
text: Okay, cool. Thank you so much, Kush.

speaker: Kush
text: Of course.
